Award.AwardTitle: Geometric Structure of the Turbulent Cascade

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The majority of fluid flows in nature and in engineering applications are turbulent. But despite being so commonplace, understanding and modeling turbulence remains a significant challenge. Turbulent flows are distinct from more general unsteady flows because they display a characteristic cascade of energy from the large length scales at which energy is generated to the small length scales on which it is dissipated by viscosity. Typically, this process is described in an abstract way that makes it difficult to appreciate the underlying physics. The goal of this proposed research is to recast the turbulent energy cascade as a mechanical process, where large scales do work on the small scales. This model immediately emphasizes the important role played by geometry, since if the forces provided by the large scales are misaligned with the flow direction, they can do no work. In this proposed research, the geometry of the turbulent cascade will be studied in detail and its links to other turbulent processes will be clarified. Ultimately, the results of this research may lead to new strategies for turbulence modeling. The proposed research will support the education and training of graduate students, and the results will be folded into existing graduate courses. Additionally, the supported scientists will participate in educational outreach activities coordinate through Stanford's Bob and Norma Street Environmental Fluid Mechanics Laboratory.

The objective of this proposed research is to gain a deeper understanding of how the geometric properties of scale-dependent turbulent stresses and strain rates and, in particular, their relative alignment control the turbulent cascade. Specifically, the alignment and possible spatial ordering of the turbulent stress and strain rate will be characterized, an understanding of how this alignment is modulated by advection will be developed, and potential links between alignment and intermittency will be investigated. These questions will be studied via theoretical work and analysis of data sets for three-dimensional turbulence, two-dimensional turbulence, and unsteady, random, and multiscale but non-turbulent velocity fields. By basing this research on sound and transparent mechanical principles of work and energy transfer, the results will bring new clarity to the origins of the detailed structure of turbulence that is more interpretable than abstract approaches such as multifractality.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Turbulence is by far the most common state of fluid flow in both environmental and engineered systems, but it remains a significant challenge to model or simulate. One of the many reasons for the lack of general-purpose models for turbulence is its inherently multiscale nature: turbulent flows are always comprised of motion on many different length and time scales. These different scales interact with each other in a way that is typically described as a cascade process, where energy enters the turbulence in its largest scales and is then transferred sequentially to smaller and smaller scales until eventually being dissipated by viscous effects. But even though the energy-cascade picture is entrenched in the turbulence community, we do not fully understand its origin or the way it operates in detail.

 

The primary goal of this project was to deepen our understanding of the turbulent energy cascade by first reconceptualizing it as a mechanical process and subsequently using that formulation to illuminate the ways that it is constrained by geometry. In a mechanics, energy transfer between two systems can always be described as one system doing work on the other. To do so, however, the stresses exerted must be appropriately aligned with the resulting strains. In turbulence, this requirement places constraints on how dynamically generated stresses and strain rates must be arranged for an energy cascade to exist.

 

To achieve this goal, we worked with three distinct data sets: a database of direct numerical simulations of turbulence, a collection of synthetic velocity fields with multiscale structure but no dynamics, and Monte Carlo sampling of the possible alignment states of the stress and the strain rate. These three distinct types of data allowed us to explore both what actually happens in turbulence as well as counterfactual worlds where specific aspects of the full turbulence dynamics were excised, so that we could understand which of these aspects are necessary to drive the observed dynamics. 

 

Even though the energy transfer between scales is one of the defining features of turbulence, we found that is a surprisingly inefficient process: even though the stresses and strains in a turbulent flow are independently large, their average alignment is poor so that much less energy is driven between scales than would be possible given optimal alignment. This result suggests that what controls the energy cascade is not necessarily the strength of the turbulent flow, but rather its geometric properties.

 

We investigated this hypothesis in more detail by mixing information about stress and strain magnitude and relative orientation from our three types of data sets, and confirmed that indeed the alignment played the dominant role in setting the properties of the energy cascade. Even more interestingly, though, we also found that there are more ways to align the stress and strain rate in a way that drives energy from large to small scales in 3D turbulence simply due to the mathematical properties of rotations in 3D space. This result suggests that at least some part of the energy cascade may arise purely from mathematics and not from any turbulent dynamics. When we investigated the same question in two dimensions, the bias toward a forward cascade disappeared; and, suggestively, it is well known that energy does not cascade to smaller scales in 2D turbulence. These results may be valuable in constructing models of turbulence, as they highlight both the important role of geometry in turbulence (which is often neglected in modeling), and point to some aspects of the dynamics that need not be modeled but instead will arise from mathematical constraints.

 

Finally, we also studied how the alignment of the stress and the strain evolved along the trajectories of fluid elements in a so-called Lagrangian analysis. We found that this alignment, which was instantaneously poor, was much stronger when we considered the stress at a point and the strain at the same spatial location but at an earlier time; that is, we found that the stress followed the strain but with a time lag. This result helps to reveal the essential dynamics that controls the alignment of these quantities. And by recasting the equations of motion in a fully Lagrangian form, we were also able to isolate the important role played by the deformation of fluid elements, another effect that is typically ignored in turbulence models. 

 

Appropriate modeling of any system requires a thorough knowledge of which features need to be modeled and which can be neglected. In a system as complex as turbulence, this division is far from obvious. The results of this project provide a new understanding of the essential elements of turbulence that must be captured to construct a viable model.
